title: How can one figure out what type of chord is being played by just listening to it? - Quora

response.answer_text: I'll preface this with the warning that reading this will be like drinking from a fire hose. Music theory is like math (literally, it uses the same part of the brain). You can't do much with a basic understanding of it. Functionality comes from practice, and it takes time. The piano is a great place to start, because notes are laid out in the most logical and conspicuous arrangement. I would get a music theory book or do some looking online to find the basic structure of a few chords.  That said, let's get started. Remember that distinguishing chords comes from a basic understanding of intervals. If you haven't learned intervals, this should come first. Assuming you know basic intervals, here are the chords you should memorize and practice (practice playing them in different keys, picking them out from songs you hear, have someone play the chords for you and guess which is played)  Major, and minor (major with the third lowered a half step) triads are the starting point with chords. (In a diminished triad, the third and fifth intervals are lowered a half step. This is a rarity in pop music).Seventh chords: (the "7th" refers to the interval between the base note and the top note that distinguishes a chord as a seventh chord) Dominant seventh: Major triad plus a minor 7thMajor seventh: Major triad plus a Major 7thMinor seventh: minor triad plus a minor 7thHalf-diminished seventh: diminished triad (minor triad with the 5th lowered a half step) plus a minor seventhFully-diminished seventh: diminished triad plus a diminished seventh interval (take the minor seventh interval and bring it another half step down).Ninth chords: Ninth chords are easer to distinguish once you've mastered the seventh chord game because they add a 9th interval to the mix (which is really the same as a 2nd interval, raised an octave.) For the ones I'll mention, quality is determined by the seventh chord under the 9th. Following are a few basic ones to get you started after you're comfortable with seventh cords.  Minor ninth: Minor seventh chord plus a major ninth (this is probably the only ninth chord you will really hear).Major ninth: Major seventh chord plus a major ninthDominant ninth: Dominant seventh chord plus a major ninth (doubt you'll need to know this one, but hey)(If you're ever playing jazz, an "add 9" refers to a triad plus a ninth, without the whole seventh chord deal. Most ninth chords, variations from what I've mentioned, and things like the half-diminished and fully-diminished sevenths, are not usually going to be heard much in pop music. But keep in mind there is far more to learn out there.) Picking chords out of songs you hear essentially comes down to two steps.  First, you need to listen the bassline. Chords can be played in different inversions, etc. Listen to what the bass is playing, so you can begin constructing the chord in your head to figure out what it is. The next step is to listen to the other notes being played and imagine them over the bass note. Generally you'll be able to distinguish major from minor easily based on the tone (as you put it, happy vs. sad). However, if you practice this enough, you'll be able to distinguish between the types of seventh (and ninth) chords that you might be hearing. Again, this takes time and lots and lots of practice.Cheers.

Sorry, but most of these answers are unnecessarily complex and detailed hogwash. They will doubtless scare away people like the OP. At 16, after I had been playing acoustic folk guitar for less than a year (without lessons other than the rankest-beginner Mel Bay book), I was able to figure out chord progressions for most songs I heard on the radio—to the point where I was able to do so for my then-boyfriend’s rock band. It doesn’t take genius, years of study or even knowledge of theory (which I didn’t even start studying till college). I could barely even sight-sing, a skill I got from high school choir. How did I learn ? By seeing the chord diagrams for each type of chord most likely to be encountered in the keys of C and G (printed above sheet music or in those Mel Bay primers), then playing them, and listening for the differences between them! I watched and listened to other players, and later watched the old PBS show “Folk Guitar with Laura Weber.” It was quite easy to extrapolate those tell-tale sound signatures to other keys once I’d heard them over and over and committed them to memory. Mind you, I was not yet a “good guitarist,” just a competent rudimentary one. Eventually, I picked up theory both by experience and formal study, and learned what the components of each type of chord were, intervals, Nashville-numbering, etc. But first I had to know what they sounded like, not what notes on the scale or staff were present in them. And there is NO substitute for listening!!!

Since this was in the “learning to play guitar” forum, and you wouldn’t be asking this question if you were very experienced, I’m going to give you a simple answer which isn’t full of confusing music theory. The easiest way to figure out chords, is to go online and search for the song you’re trying to play, to see if there’s a posted version with chords and lyrics (so you can know where each chord goes by following the lyrics). And make sure it’s chords and not tablature, which is similar but works differently. That’s all there is to it and if you do this enough, you’ll eventually start figuring it out yourself without having to find them online. However: If you want to figure it out for yourself, a fairly simple method is to play a single note on your top string that seems to match the sound of the chord. If the note you find is a “G”, then the chord is most likely a G of some sort as well. You’ll have to determine whether or not it’s a major, minor, or 7th by trying all three, but you’ve done the hardest part already. If you’re a beginner, there’s little reason for you to worry about all the other chords at this point. Even 7ths aren’t nearly as important as basic majors and minors. A good beginner’s exercise is to try to discover them for yourself, and then look up a chord and lyrics chart online to see how close you were, or just learn what the key is in (more on this below) and figure it out from there. Do this a couple of times and you’ll start to get the hang of it. Identifying chords takes some practice, so don’t get discouraged. The good part is that if you spend 15 minutes trying to determine a certain chord, tomorrow might just take 5 minutes. And from there, it will just get easier and quicker. I can sometimes guess the majority of a song without having an instrument nearby. You’ll also be learning a lot of other important stuff as you go along that’s mostly related to music theory. Those things are important, but if you continue to learn the basics, at some point you’ll be able to have someone teach you all of that other stuff and it will actually make sense instead of simply confusing you. Along with learning chords, also learn what a “Key” is. (Once you determine that first chord or two, you’ll have a good idea what key the song is in.) Knowing the key automatically tells you what most of the chords will be, which will make it a lot easier to figure something out. A lot of beginner guitarists are playing classic rock or country. Most of those songs can be played with 3-5 chords and a lot of time they’ll even be the same chords (singers tend to use only one or two keys throughout an entire album). Obviously, there are songs that have a lot more chords, but stick to the easier ones until you’re ready. AC/DC, KISS, and other stuff like that is fairly easy for a beginner if you’re playing classic rock, and older country (like Willie Nelson or George Jones) is easy if you’re trying to play that style. Newer country is all over the place, so it’s a little unpredictable as is most Pop music. Since you’re at the beginner’s stage, I’ll give you a word of advice: spend only half your time on chords. Spend the other half on rhythm. You’d be surprised how many musicians can play lead notes all over the neck but are terrible rhythm guitarists (this is common with most instruments). Their timing is simply bad. Remember that music is “pitch” (the note you’re playing) and “rhythm” (when you’re playing that note). One isn’t worth much without the other. As an exercise, find a simple song you like and play a recording of it. Play a single chord and see if you can match the rhythm of the song from one end to the other. If you can’t, you need to keep doing this at least as much as you’re practicing chords. And just like chords, there are nearly as many rhythms (and people will notice when you’re playing them badly a lot quicker than they’ll notice a bad chord.) Good luck!

This is a bit tricky but you might want to give a shot. Listen for the bass notes. They are often the lowest note of the chord and they are often the most supportive note of the chord. When you can define (or play) the bass note, the next step is to decide whether it is a major or a minor chord. This part is easy, if the bass note is an E note then play an E major chord, if it sounds a bit sour then play an E minor chord. Stay away from 7th chords at first. The 3rd note of any chord has great power because it defines whether the chord is a major or a minor chord. The note name of the chord is not always the bass note. The 5th tone is often used as the bass note also. You can use this method to track down the chord tones. In the key of C, the note names are C, D, E, F, G, A, B, C. You can add numbers to the note names: 1C, 2D, 3E, 4F, 5G, 6A, 7B, 8C. Chord tones are the odd numbers (1, 3, 5, and 7. The 8th tone is a clone of the first note. Each note of the scale can become a root note. If you take each note of the C scale and place it as the first note you can create a model for all the chords of the C scale. Use the numbers to identify the notes of each start sequence. The first set is 1C to 8C the next is 1D to 8D, all the other notes follow this arrangement. When you want to find the chord for each set you only have to select the 1, 3, 5, and/or 7th notes to play all the chords in the C scale. Take your time to work this out because this system can applied to all the major scales and the minor scales contained within. Once you get the drift you won’t want to stop using this method. Good luck! P.S. the chords of the C scale are as follows: Cmaj, Dmin, Emin, Fmaj, G, Amin, Bdim, and C. Each chord gets to be part of a scale within a scale! Go exploring!

When I was in middle school, about 8th grade, I had a little book called something like "How to Write Rock 'n' Roll Music" This would have been about 1968 or so.It was an epiphany to me, an eye-opener and the key to music. I wish I still had it, or could find it again. I've tried. This little book was essentially a theory primer - it talked about the basic construction of songs, what we call I, IV, V chords; often in the pattern of 1, 4, 1, 5seventh, 1 (Or C, F, C, G7, C), and how ubiquitous this is through popular music. Then it broadened it adding "relative minors" which are sort of like those chords and substitute for them, giving sort of a "do-wap" sound. Once you start to understand the structure (and early Rock, or even better, 12 bar blues is very pure on this harmonic structure) you start to hear it everywhere. Having a framework on which to hang the sounds makes it easy to understand what chord you are hearing. And then, like those "relative minors" you can start to hear variations from the pure framework, and diminished, augmented, 6ths, 9ths, etc. start to open up. Because you now have a context. At that time, I had taken piano for more years than I had been in school, and was a pretty new guitar player. But it was all just jumbled up bits of knowledge -do this, then do that until the end of the song.When I learned this little bit of theory, I started to be able to figure things out, to hear that structure, and hear the chords (even hear what the chords would be if there WERE chords!) in a completely new way. That little book rocked my world.A little theory can be a good thing.

There's a huge amount of theory here, but if that's not your thing (it sure isn't mine) I don't think its any more complicated than familiarity. Over time, if you actively exercise your ears and brain, you will come to distinguish the finer subtleties of chords. By "actively exercise" I mean: listen to a song repeatedly (internalization is a massive part of this)Find the chords as best you can (even if they are just minor and major for now). By find I mean, find them yourself on your instrument. Not Google it or use some tech to shortcut, because its the process of you doing it that will develop your earAllow yourself to then check tab/google it/ use tech to find one of the chords to confirm /check your answerIf your chord wasn't quite right, play yours and then play the correct chord and notice the differenceRepeatOften you can tell the diference between open chords and barre chords by the difference in sustain and interval order. Intervals in a open G for example are: Root, 3rd, 5th, root, 3rd, root While a barred version has: Root, 5th, root, 3rd, 5th, root. This ability along with many others centred around listening and identifying musical elements like chords, scales, riffs and melodies can be learned and honed with regular Ear Training practice. Once developed, your sharpened ability will mean you won't have to hunt around on your instrument to find chords, riff etc but know exactly where to put your fingers.

Each of those chords (minor 7, major 7, dominant 7th has a particular character based on the intervals contained within the chords. As others suggest, you should practice listening, singing and playing intervals to start. I also like the idea of associating a visual image/character to chords or associating them with a song I know well. For example, fully diminished chords sound like the bad guy tying the woman to the train tracks in old tv shows and the major minor seventh chord sounds like a detective working in a city filled with dark alleyways and dangerous criminals. Dominant seventh chords have a particular dissonance built in- a diminished fifth as a result of its major third and its flat seventh combined- when the third is flattened to a minor third, this dissonance goes away since the interval becomes a perfect fifth. You want to listen for this tension- minor seventh chords don't have much tension, especially when compared to a dominant seventh chord. Major seventh chords have more tension because the major seventh forms a minor second when voiced close to its root. It's also literally a major chord and a minor chord together (C major seventh is CEG and EGB combined for example) and to me sounds like wistful remembrances of a wonderful time in the past that can no longer happen again. Try to tell yourself a story with these sounds and recall the story when you hear those sounds later. Good luck!

I am not a music teacher, but this is how I learned from my guitar teacher and it helped put it all in perspective. The first step in understanding how a chord sounds is to understand how they are built. For example a major chord sounds “happy” because it is built off of the 1–3–5 intervals - otherwise known as a major triad. So to make a “C” chord you would use the notes C (1) - E(3) and G (5). I purposely used “C” in this example because the “C” intervals are the easiest to see. C (1) D(2) E(3) F(4) G(5) A(6) B(7) C (1 - Back to the Root). Remember that between B & C and E & F there are 1/2 steps so that confuses things a little bit when you build chords. Now that you know this, you can see where everywhere on the guitar neck or piano keyboard there is a C you can build a C chord very easily - just add the 3rd and 5th note. You can also build inversions or different variations of those chords. If you want to build a minor chord you have to use the 1 - 3(minor) - 5 intervals. Which means that in our “C” chord example you would use C(1) - EMinor(flat3) - G(5). That flatted (moved down a 1/2 step or 1 fret) third makes all of the difference in the world because that is what makes it “sad”. Once you see how chords are built and do it yourself by adding 7ths, flat 7th’s, 6th’s and 9th’s (otherwise known as “2’s” because once you “pass” the 2 in the line up the interval you have to call it a 9th — 11th’s are just 4th’s) you get to see where the sounds come from. For a Major 7 chord you would use 1 - 3 - 5 - 7. In a dominant 7th chord you would add a flat 7 (1 - 3 - 5 - minor7). That flatted 7th note adds such a unique sound that you will recognize it a lot easier once you hear it built into the major chord and you will hear it all over blues and rock. Throw in the 1 - flat3rd - 5 - flat7 and you now have a Minor 7th chord. Starting to get the picture? Don’t forget the Devil’s interval which is a flatted 5th - the ultimate “note” in any “Metal” song - it will show you how just one note makes all the difference! The key to all of this is 1) knowing the intervals on your instrument. If you know the intervals it’s not nearly as important to memorize the notes - you will learn them over time. If you know the notes and the intervals you are even better off. If you memorize all of the intervals (ex: minor 7 flat 5 = 1 - flat3 - flat5 - flat7) in all of the chord types (major / minor / dominant / 7th’s / 9th’s / 11th’s + suspended and augmented chords and triads) and in all of the modes and scales (blues / harmonic minor) you will be a kick-ass musician because you will understand what is going on and won’t be limited by playing stuff that you have just memorized. When you are jamming with other people and someone is playing rhythm you can move in and out and all around without playing the same chords that they are playing and can add extra spice. It takes years but when you get there you will be in the top 1%. I have attached the chord and interval chart that I made when I was trying to learn all of this stuff. Hope it helps! Intervals.pdf

There are many ways to approach this, and some great answers here. I especially like Tali's suggestion of working with stripped down intervals. Pretty important if you want to get deep into hearing chords. Since you ask about hearing chord extensions, I think it might help to frame your listening exercises with a little chord theory. Essentially this is a framework for doing the interval work that Tali recommends. Let's start with a relatively dense chord: Cmaj7#11 1 - 3 - 5 - 7 - #11 (intervals)C - E - G - B - F# (pitches)Here we can group the chord tones into two main groups: stable tones and color tones. This helps us break up a complex harmony into discernible parts, so we can take it one bite at a time. Stable tones define the chord. Cmaj7#11 is just a C major chord with a few added tones. The intervals which build a C major chord - 1, 3, 5 - are stable tones. Stable tones ground the harmony, and color tones only make sense when played with (against) a set of stable tones. Color tones add flavor. They combine in subtle and diverse ways. It helps to think about color tones on a continuum from consonant to dissonant. In the case of Cmaj7#11, 7 and #11 are both color tones, but the 7th sounds more consonant than the #11. The #11 sounds considerably more "outside."  So, here's how you learn to hear a complex chord like Cmaj7#11. First, you must learn to hear the stable tones and how they relate to each other. Start with interval pairs. Learn to hear 1 & 3, 3 & 5, 1 & 5. Then work with 3 note voicings. Stacking these intervals on guitar is a lot of fun. You'll amaze yourself with the many ways you can play a C major chord: 1, 3, 53, 5, 15, 1, 3etc.Once you can hear the stable tones, then you can learn to hear color tones in order from consonant to dissonant. The common consonant color tones you'll encounter are 7, 6, 9. Dissonant color tones are more varied, but it's good to start with b9, #9, #11. A note about learning color tones. Learn them one interval at a time. It's much easier to distinguish Cmaj7 from C7 than it is to distinguish Cmaj7#11 from C7#11. Why? Cmaj7 and C7 have only 4 notes, and 3 in common. The only difference is the 7th, which is flattened in a C7 chord (C-E-G-Bb). Once you can hear a C chord, it's not too difficult to distinguish C7 & Cmaj7. Cmaj7#11 and C7#11 each contain 5 notes, offering more possible inversions and interval combinations. There's a lot of tension: 7 against 1, #11 against 1, #11 against 7. But if you start with Cmaj7 and C7 it's not so bad. Once you can hear those chords, and you can hear a #11 interval against the root... then it's only a little more practice before you can call out a Cmaj7#11 in your sleep!

It's actually something that comes quite easily with practice. The thing is, unless you have perfect pitch, musicians wouldn't immediately know the exact chord that is being played. I'll walk you through the thought process that can easily distinguish the chord progression of a song. A major scale has 7 notes (8 if you count the very last repeated note). Think “Do - Re - Mi”. Each of these notes can be associated with a number 1–7. If you never use a note that is outside of these 7 notes of the scale (which is very noticeable if you do), you will only have 7 chords to choose from. Of these 7 chords, a few of them are rather irrelevant. One specific chord is the 7th chord (in the key of C, it would be B diminished… you won't find this chord on the radio 99.9% of the time). So that leaves just 6 chords to choose from. Of these 6, there are 4 that are very common. The 1, 4, 5, and 6. Here's the catch - you wouldnt be able to know “this is a G chord” unless you knew the key of the song. So, knowing the key is actually the first step. Without that, you're just as in the dark as anyone else (again, unless you have perfect pitch). Now, you just need to train your ear to be able to identify the intervalic differences in these chords. As simple as I can put it, the 5 chord naturally pulls to the 1 chord (or to the 6 chord.. but this is called a deceptive cadence because it technically does resolve, but not in the way you thought it would). The 6 chord sounds minor, and the four chord typically leads to the 4. None of these things are necessarily “rules", they just help identify where a song is going.

Honestly, I think there are three kinds of people when it comes to music. The people who don't get it, the people who do, and the people who really do. I perhaps situate myself in the "people who do" get music. But not "really do" because I don't understand the mechanics, the technicalities of it. Yes I know that a major key is different from a minor key and that only a specific set of chords belong to an E Major Key which is different from playing in the B Minor Key.   But look: One of my favorite "go to" songs is Taylor Swift's "Our Song" and I just happen to know that the song begins with a D Major chord. So, if I am out in the car listening to a song, or just trying to pick out a song, I could pick up a D Major just simply because I recognize it.  And the best part is, you can do this with all the chords! But if I were you, I would start out simple, starting with the less complex chords such as D, Em, Am, G, and slowly build your list of chords you can recognize.  Good luck!

Chords happen in context. As a musician, I don't think much about individual chords anymore - I think about sequences of chords, that follow the Circle of Fifths and other common rules of harmony, and creating those harmonic motions via voice leading. So if I hear a iim7-V7-I sequence, I know that middle chord is a dominant seventh, by its function. From there, I learn things like how it sounds if altered - say, IIb9-V+7-I (Dflat9 to Gaugmented7 to C, for example). By hearing the core function automatically, I can learn to pick out the alterations and substitutions.  It's hard to explain this without experiencing it. It's like asking "How do you know which words to put together to make a sentence?" When you start, you think of notes, so you're thinking of letters. Then you move to chords, and you're thinking of words. I'm talking about thinking in sentences.  And when I'm playing music seriously and well, I'm not even thinking sentences. I'm thinking paragraphs, or pages. Isolating a single chord from a stream of structured music is like isolating a single word from a page of music and wondering what it means. Every word is important (hopefully), but not every word has significance outside the context of the page.

I want to answer this as concisely as possible. I started taking lessons at age 9 and have learned several musical instruments over the course of 21 years. I am a recording artist with 11 albums and I’ve opened a music lesson business, teaching locally from a brick and mortar, as well as online. My first tip is avoiding gurus and any method that promises what seems like you’ll gain magical ear-powers. My second tip is to practice a musical instrument for life and expect to always be getting better. If your practicing is sincere and you are being honest with yourself, with rational expectations, you must trust you are getting better like you trust your hair is growing (i.e. you will not necessarily see it happening, at least not all the time). Tip three is to learn musical theory. This is one of the hardest things, only because most books are written pretentiously and/or the authors write in a manner to avoid criticism from other professors or to impress, and many teachers want to be gurus who’s status is dependent on being the only one “in the know”. Learning music theory should be fun and exciting to an aspiring musician/artist. Tip four is to take mental note of chords that sound cool to you when you play them - if you hear a chord that sounds cool to you in a song, learn it - and identify at least the chord type by name. Later study the context of the chord (i.e. how it relates to the chords around it.) I also recommend singing the intervals in chords you are studying. Tip five is to only try learn learn one chord type at a time. If you are trying to identify Maj7 chords and you are using a random chord generator, ask yourself merely whether the chord you hear is Maj7 or not. Don’t try to internalize the sound every chord at once and then expect yourself to be able to distinguish between them. Bonus tip - This is a life pursuit. There is no finish line. Understand that this is good news!

The other answers given are very good, but maybe too technical or advanced for a player like me. I’m an ear player, and not a very good one if I’m honest. I don’t really know any theory. I can usually find a chord pretty quickly and this is how I do it. First of all I can tell if it’s a major (happy) minor (sad) 7th (funky) minor 7th (funky sad) easily. Then I find a root note on the 6th or 5th string and play a couple of barre shapes on that fret. If its a chord with an add9 or a 5th or something weird i just kind of find it. This works for about 95% of chords in most music other than jazz. Those jazz guys are crazy with the weird chords. The other 5% I sometimes have to admit defeat and google it. I know quite a lot of players who do it like this, and one or two of them are really great guitarists who make their living from it, but really it’s better to understand the theory like Jake Doering is saying.

Many individuals have offered some really great answers. My answer is quite simple. I learned to recognize the type of chord I’m hearing by reading jazz charts, playing the chords represented by the chord symbol (C, F#m7, Abmaj7, Bb6/9, etc.), and over time, associating the symbol with the sound coming from my instrument. One can learn organically by seeing a chord symbol, playing the chord it represents on one’s instrument, and hearing the sound it makes. Of course, this takes patience and time to become proficient at it. It’s not unlike learning to read aloud. You see a word on the page, someone pronounces it for you, you hear the pronunciation of the word, and try to reproduce it with your own voice. In time, you see the word on the page and you know what it will sound like when you read it. Similarly, you hear a word spoken, and you know how that word will look in written form. Hope that helps.

One of the techniques that really helped me with this stuff was to connect the sound of particular chords with either a picture in my head or a particular song or style of music. Some examples:Dom#9 - The main riff from Purple Haze by Jimi HendrixMaj7 - I picture the cliche lounge jazz performerDom7 - The turn-around in a 12-bar bluesMaj6 - The end of lots of Beatles songs As Stephen said, start with the easy ones and gradually get more complex.  As you're playing with the chord, create a visual picture in your head of what the chord sounds like.  Whatever that is to you.  Maybe a 13 chord sounds "partly cloudy with a chance of rain".  Those visual connections help immensely. You might also do the same thing individual intervals.  A lot of time, being able to hear the correct intervals in the melody will clue you in to what the underlying chord is.  Here's some tips on that: How to Learn Intervals by Ear

The shortest answer to that will be ear training. Learn to recognize the root note of the chord and the notes which follow it. Learn your intervals (they're probably the simplest part of ear training) and try to associate the notes you hear with the intervals. Learn how chords are constructed (example 1-3-5 for major, 1-b3-5 for minor) and spend some time familiarising yourself with how they sound. You mentioned earlier that you can already recognize major and minor chords. If you listen carefully you'll find that most chords are similar to them with a few extra notes.  Say someone asks you to distinguish between an augmented and a diminished chord. You can think of it as 'an augmented chord has a higher note attached to the major chord while a diminished has a lower note'. Listen to these chords and you'll know what I mean. Train your ear well :)

Here’s an odd trick that helped me greatly to determine keys and chord progressions of popular songs. Somewhere, I read results of research that recorded random people asked to sing the opening lines to “Hotel California.” It turned out virtually all the people sang within a semi-tone of the original Eagles’ version. From then on, when I was trying to suss out the first chord(s) of a song by ear, I would sing the beginning of the melody and attempt match it with a common chord. It worked like crazy! And – as others have noted – once you have the first chord, there is usually a relatively small list of “the usual suspects” of other chords making up the song. (Example: first chord is G. Likely other chords used in the song include C, D, Bm, A, Am, Em – maybe F and Dm.)

The shortest answer is “yes”, and I have seen people do this. I can’t! But when I was high school my friend and I ( he was then and is now a brilliant tenor sax player) were trying to figure out the chords to a tune fromnthe band that would become Steely Dan. So there were not simple triads, they were fairly complex extended chords. Turns out my friends mom, a violinist, had perfect pitch. We asked her to help us figure out the chords. She listened once, writing down the chords complete with all tensions. She listened a second time, she only had to change one chord’s extensions, and that was that. I was beyond impressed. She did not have to try them out on piano, but we did to check her and if she was wrong it was so close that we could ’t tell. I mean she listed the inversions in the piano part! Pretty darned cool. She could also tell you what notes the door bell or car door chime was, and if they were a little sharp or flat.

Like the other answers say, practice is really the way to go. And there are lots of good ways to go about it. I just want to add that distinguishing notes, intervals and chords Is using your ears to interpret sound wavelengths in the same way that distinguishing color is using your eyes to interpret light wavelengths. So it is possible to have disorders (like color blindness) that makes it more difficult to distinguish. But as other responders have indicated, there are great ways to train your ears and brain, and thousands of music students have to do it every year to pass their music theory classes. That was one of my favorite subjects in high school and college, because my mom helped me train from a very young age. So a lot of those exercises and skills came more easily than they would have if I had tried to learn it all as a young adult.

You need and instrument and need to know how to form chords. My mother used to cheat. They played accordion and accordions have major, minor, minor 7th, 7th, major 7th, augments, diminished, 9ths on the left hand (all those push buttons. So if I played her a Beatles song she press a button until it gave her the same sound as the chord they were playing. Generally you can get away with just majors and minors, Then 7th and minor 7ths. Those usually comprise the chords to MOST songs. Beatles, Jim Web and a few others get exotic with major minors and 11th and G9th add 5th.

It takes a lot of experience. Just keep on learning new chords and patterns and then one day you'll be amazed on how fast can you figure out the chords of a song. I don't know if this will work for you but it worked for me: 1. Listen2. Try to figure out the chords used3. Repeat You won't notice the changes but sure you will be familiar with the sound as you accumulate experience. I didn't notice how I got mine. Just like tuning a guitar.

Usually by the chords that surround it, you start off with your main chord and go from there but it's according what type of music too. I play Old Country and gospel and some rockabilly and they usually just use three to four chords maybe a fifth one in there the fourth and fifth ones are usually minors, hope this helps. Usually music is in ABC's if you start off in A then you skip two letters in the alphabet and your next two letters areD&E your next chords, if you start off in G you start over in a in the alphabet so you skip a and b you skipped two letters in the alphabet you're next two letters are your next chords. So on and so forth . Not counting the flats. It's actually pretty simple once you start doing this your fourth chord I call this my off cord is usually the next letter in the alphabet after the third, try it it works. Just try it! I'm tired of editing it

A simple way to learn this is to listen too as much music as you can and follow along on a lead sheet or an analysis. This may sound simple, but it takes time. It’s like children learn language and grammar – not by reading grammar books, but by listening to people talking until they get a “feel” for what it is they hear. I do harmonic analysis videos of current pop songs on YouTube: Real World Music Theory Channel . This can be a fun way to develop the “feeling” for chords. Also be sure to try to play with songs you hear – it might not be perfect in the beginning, but you will learn pretty quickly.

I am semi-tone deaf, so I play mostly by theory. I think it's a result of coming as close as you can to having perfect pitch. It's as close as having a blind person being able to differentiate colors by perception.(that's what it sounds like to a tone deaf person) I've been at a recording studio and when 1 of 3 vocals being recorded at the same time is out of tune and they can "hear" which one is the culprit, to me, it's mind boggling. So, the advice is, practice, practice and more practice!

Simply put, you don’t figure it out, you recognize it instantly. Learn to recognize chord structure, how the root, third, and fifth all go together. In A, 1, 3, and 5 are A, C#, and E. That’s the root, third, and fifth. Play them in that order and end it with a higher A. Up and down, learn how that sounds. Then “flat the 3rd” to play A, C, and E. That’s an A minor chord. Play that up and down, and of course all together, and learn what a minor chord sounds like. Minor chords are typically ‘sad’ chords. Almost anything Russian sounds sad. (usually was) Major chords are happy chords. There are other notes like the 7 and 9, and of course a million others. This chord structure will apply to any instrument. Music is music. Enjoy!

Do you mean just the type of chord (major, minor, diminished, etc.) or the actual notes in the chord? Well, either way, you have to hear what notes are being played. Go step by step. Try to duplicate the lowest note in the chord. Then try to duplicate the highest note. Then work on the intermediate notes. At this point even by trial and error you should be able to hear which notes are consonant with the chord and which dissonant.

Try using my music theory app for 15 minutes every day. It teaches the fundamental of chord structures within scales and also includes audio so learners learn what each chord sounds like relative to the tonic chord within that scale. I've made a short demonstration video of how to use the app:

Absolutely this can be learned. The more complex "jazzy" chords are obviously more difficult, but start with major and minor. Once you get that, add diminished and augmented. Then add suspended. Then add 7ths, etc...  This doesn't require Perfect ("Absolute") Pitch, just careful ear training.

If you are listening to chords played on the guitar and if you are a guitar player, you can not only figure out the type of chord but the note as well. For example, with some basic ear training, chords such as Aadd9, Amin, Bmin (relative to D), B7, Cmaj, Cmaj7, C7, C7sus4, Dmaj, Dus2, Dsus4, D7, Emaj/Emin, Fmaj, Gmaj, G7 are easy to pick up when played in familiar positions.
Keep in mind, if you are tone deaf and cannot sing back a note which has been given to you (voice quality not important) you will probably never be able to identify chords just by listening to them.

Get yourself a comprehensive guitar chord book then learn all the various shapes by their root note up and down the neck. Before long you'll remember the tone associated with each chord shape, too. You'll even recognize a chord if only a portion of it is played when you hear it.
Listen to a chord over and over again, and try to analyze what all notes are being played inside it. Use an instrument if possible; preferably a piano/keyboard.It takes time and concentration.
I find that the more chords I play the easier it is to pick them out when I hear them played by others.

I don't know how to explain it, but I took one guitar lesson and quit. but I learned how to play many songs just by ear. main thing is try to open you mind and hear all the instruments. leave the lyrics out of it. I know it may sound corny, but feel the music.
Ear Training. I just wrote an ear training app for Mac OSX. It’s free and in the App Store under Categories->Music. Look for Phil’s Ear Trainer. I’m pretty sure there are similar apps for Windows.

Simpe Funda: 1 scale has 12 Notes :C,C#, D,D#,E,F,G,G#,A,A#,B After this, similar pattern repeats Or, strt with any upper note & proceed similar way.... But a song can be made by choosing any 7 notes out of them..... Sometimes 8/9/10... Rarely....Try to catch these 7 notes or rare one other than basic 7. Use them to play.... Cheers!!!
This is a skill gained from ear training. There are a number of sites on the web that have exercises for identifying intervals and chord types, such as musictheory.net
